questions.question: ‘OK everybody, lunch break is over. Now get back to the …………………...’
questions.description: To be back to the grind is to get back to work.

questions.question: ‘Did you get that job?’ ‘No mate, I ………………………… it.’
questions.description: I blew it = I missed my opportunity

questions.question: Her dreams of becoming a famous actor ended up just being a ……………………….. in the sky.
questions.description: Pie in the Sky = an unrealistic dream

questions.question: It was a ……………………. plan, so nobody was surprised when it failed.
questions.description: If something is half-baked, it hasn't been properly thought out or planned.

questions.question: …………………….. in there. Things should get better soon.
questions.description: This is an expression used to encourage people who are in a difficult situation.

questions.question: Writers of his caliber are hard to ………………………… by.
questions.description: If something is hard to come by, it is difficult to find.

questions.question: She was hot under the ……………………… when she heard that they had lost that contract.
questions.description: If you are hot under the collar, you are angry or annoyed about something.

questions.question: I’m ……………………… and tired of eating the same thing for dinner every day.
questions.description: When you are sick and tired of something, you no longer find it interesting or exciting.

questions.question: Your radio is starting to get on my ………………………. You had better it turn it down.
questions.description: To get on somebody’s nerves is to annoy them.

questions.question: It is a small job but I am going to accept it. At least, I’ll have my ……………………. in the door.
questions.description: To get your foot in the door is to accept even a small job hoping that you would be able to get a promotion before long.

questions.question: You don’t have to pay for my drinks. Let’s go ………………………..
questions.description: To go Dutch is to pay your own share.

questions.question: He tends to sell himself …………………… and that is his main fault.
questions.description: To sell somebody short is to describe them as less impressive than they really are.
